metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Calculate magnetic flux when the magnetic field is perpendicular to the area, and describe the qualitative effect of differing angles between the area and the field: Φ_B = B⊥A

magnetic_flux_definition.name: Magnetic Flux Definition
magnetic_flux_definition.correct: Magnetic flux is the total magnetic field passing through a given area, measured in weber (Wb).

magnetic field strength.error: Field strength (B) and flux (Φ) are different quantities.
magnetic field strength.fix: B is field per unit area (tesla). Flux Φ is field × area (weber).
magnetic field strength.action: Check units: B is in T, flux is in Wb = T·m².

number of magnets.error: Flux depends on field lines through an area, not magnet count.
number of magnets.fix: Flux = B × A. It measures how much field passes through the area.
number of magnets.action: Think of flux as 'how much field' goes through a loop.

force on a wire.error: Force and flux are unrelated quantities.
force on a wire.fix: Flux is about field through an area. Force is F = BIL on a wire.
force on a wire.action: Different concepts: flux for induction, force for motor effect.

persistent.gap: You're confusing magnetic flux with other magnetic quantities.
persistent.action: Make a table: Field B (T), Flux Φ (Wb), Force F (N). Different units, different meanings.

flux_unit.name: Unit of Magnetic Flux
flux_unit.correct: The weber (Wb) is the SI unit of magnetic flux. 1 Wb = 1 T·m².

tesla.error: Tesla is the unit of field strength, not flux.
tesla.fix: Tesla measures field per unit area. Weber measures total field through an area.
tesla.action: Φ = BA, so units are T × m² = Wb.

ampere.fix: Current (A) flows in wires. Flux (Wb) passes through areas.
ampere.action: Current and flux are linked by induction, but have different units.

volt.fix: EMF (V) is induced BY changing flux, but EMF is not flux itself.
volt.action: Faraday's law: ε = −NΔΦ/Δt. Voltage comes from changing flux.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the electromagnetic units.
persistent.action: List: B in tesla (T), Φ in weber (Wb), ε in volt (V), I in ampere (A).

flux_formula_structure.name: Magnetic Flux Formula
flux_formula_structure.correct: Magnetic flux equals the perpendicular magnetic field strength multiplied by the area: Φ_B = B⊥A.

Φ = B/A.error: Wrong operation. Flux is multiplication, not division.
Φ = B/A.fix: Φ = B × A. Larger area means more flux.
Φ = B/A.action: Check: doubling area should double flux, not halve it.

Φ = B + A.error: You cannot add field and area. Different quantities.
Φ = B + A.fix: Φ = B × A. Multiplication combines different quantities.
Φ = B + A.action: Units must work: T + m² makes no sense. T × m² = Wb.

Φ = A/B.fix: Φ = B × A. More field or more area gives more flux.
Φ = A/B.action: Think: stronger field through bigger loop = more flux.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering how the formula combines B and A.
persistent.action: Write Φ = BA five times. Then calculate flux for B = 2 T and A = 0.5 m².

perpendicular_field.name: Perpendicular Field Requirement
perpendicular_field.formula: B⊥ means B perpendicular to area
perpendicular_field.correct: Only the component of magnetic field perpendicular to the loop area contributes to flux.

parallel to the area.error: Parallel field passes alongside the loop, not through it.
parallel to the area.fix: Only perpendicular field lines pass THROUGH the loop area.
parallel to the area.action: Tilt a hoop in rain: water passes through when rain hits the face, not the edge.

tangent to the area.error: Tangent means touching the edge, not passing through.
tangent to the area.fix: Flux requires field to penetrate the area, not skim past it.
tangent to the area.action: Perpendicular means 90° to the surface. Field must hit the face.

at any angle.error: Only the perpendicular component contributes at non-90° angles.
at any angle.fix: For VCE: calculate flux only when field is perpendicular to area.
at any angle.action: At other angles, flux is reduced. Maximum when field is perpendicular.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what 'perpendicular to area' means.
persistent.action: Draw a loop. Draw field lines going through it at 90°. That's perpendicular.

flux_proportionality_B.name: Flux-Field Proportionality
flux_proportionality_B.correct: Magnetic flux is directly proportional to magnetic field strength. Double B means double Φ.

inversely proportional to B.error: Opposite relationship. Stronger field gives more flux.
inversely proportional to B.fix: Φ = BA. B is in the numerator, so Φ increases with B.
inversely proportional to B.action: Calculate: if B doubles and A stays same, Φ doubles.

independent of B.error: Flux definitely depends on field strength.
independent of B.fix: Φ = BA shows direct dependence on B.
independent of B.action: No field (B = 0) means no flux. Field matters.

proportional to B squared.error: No squaring in the flux formula.
proportional to B squared.fix: Φ = BA, not Φ = B²A. First power of B.
proportional to B squared.action: Check formula: just B times A, no exponents.

persistent.gap: You're not reading proportionality from formulas correctly.
persistent.action: In Φ = BA, identify what Φ is proportional to. No fraction or square means direct proportion.

flux_proportionality_A.name: Flux-Area Proportionality
flux_proportionality_A.correct: Magnetic flux is directly proportional to loop area. Double A means double Φ.

inversely proportional to A.error: Opposite relationship. Larger area catches more flux.
inversely proportional to A.fix: Φ = BA. A is in the numerator, so Φ increases with A.
inversely proportional to A.action: Bigger fishing net catches more fish. Bigger loop catches more flux.

independent of A.fix: Φ = BA shows direct dependence on A.
independent of A.action: Zero area loop catches zero flux. Area matters.

proportional to A squared.error: No squaring of area in the flux formula.
proportional to A squared.fix: Φ = BA, not Φ = BA². First power of A.
proportional to A squared.action: Don't confuse area calculation (πr²) with flux formula (BA).

persistent.gap: You're confusing how area appears in different formulas.
persistent.action: Φ = BA uses area directly. Area of circle = πr² uses r squared. Different formulas.

angle_maximum_flux.name: Maximum Flux Angle
angle_maximum_flux.formula: Maximum when loop perpendicular to field
angle_maximum_flux.correct: Flux is maximum when the plane of the loop is perpendicular to the magnetic field direction.

parallel to the field.error: Parallel orientation gives zero flux, not maximum.
parallel to the field.fix: Parallel means field slides past the loop edge. No field goes through.
parallel to the field.action: Hold paper parallel to falling rain: nothing passes through.

at 45 degrees.fix: Maximum occurs at 90° (perpendicular). Any tilt reduces flux.
at 45 degrees.action: Tilt the loop and fewer field lines pass through it.

at any angle.fix: Only perpendicular orientation gives maximum. Other angles reduce flux.
at any angle.action: Compare: hoop facing the rain vs tilted. Which catches more?

persistent.gap: You don't visualise how loop orientation affects field capture.
persistent.action: Draw field lines and a loop at different angles. Count lines through the loop each time.

angle_zero_flux.name: Zero Flux Angle
angle_zero_flux.formula: Zero when loop parallel to field
angle_zero_flux.correct: Flux is zero when the plane of the loop is parallel to the magnetic field direction.

perpendicular to the field.error: Perpendicular gives maximum flux, not zero.
perpendicular to the field.fix: Perpendicular means the loop face catches all the field lines.
perpendicular to the field.action: Hold paper facing the rain: maximum water passes through.

at 90 degrees.error: 90° between loop plane and field gives maximum flux.
at 90 degrees.fix: Zero flux when field runs along the loop plane, not through it.
at 90 degrees.action: 90° to the field = perpendicular = maximum. 0° to field = parallel = zero.

at 45 degrees.fix: Zero only when completely parallel. Any tilt gives some flux.
at 45 degrees.action: At 45°, some field still passes through. Only at 0° is flux zero.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the angle conditions for maximum and zero flux.
persistent.action: Draw three loops: perpendicular (max), 45° (some), parallel (zero). Label each.

flux_field_lines.name: Flux as Field Lines
flux_field_lines.formula: Φ = number of field lines through area
flux_field_lines.correct: Flux can be visualised as the total number of magnetic field lines passing through the loop area.

field lines around the loop.error: Lines around the loop don't contribute to flux.
field lines around the loop.fix: Only lines passing THROUGH the enclosed area count.
field lines around the loop.action: Draw a loop. Only count lines that pierce the surface, not lines outside.

field lines per unit area.error: That describes field strength B, not flux Φ.
field lines per unit area.fix: B = lines per m². Φ = total lines through the whole area.
field lines per unit area.action: B is density of lines. Φ is total lines. Different concepts.

length of field lines.error: Line length is irrelevant to flux.
length of field lines.fix: Flux counts how many lines pass through, not how long they are.
length of field lines.action: A short line through the loop contributes just like a long one.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly visualising what flux represents.
persistent.action: Draw a uniform field (parallel lines) and a loop. Count lines through the loop = flux.

changing_flux_methods.name: Methods to Change Flux
changing_flux_methods.correct: Flux through a loop can change by varying field strength, loop area, or angle between field and loop.

only by moving the magnet.error: There are multiple ways to change flux.
only by moving the magnet.fix: Can also rotate the loop, change its size, or use an electromagnet to vary B.
only by moving the magnet.action: List four methods: change B, change A, rotate loop, move in/out of field.

only by changing current.error: Current changes are one method, but not the only one.
only by changing current.fix: Moving loops, rotating loops, or changing area all change flux too.
only by changing current.action: Generators rotate loops to change flux without changing field strength.

flux cannot be changed.fix: That's the whole point of electromagnetic induction: changing flux induces EMF.
flux cannot be changed.action: If flux never changed, generators wouldn't work.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the multiple ways to change flux.
persistent.action: For each of the four methods (B, A, angle, position), describe one real device that uses it.

area_calculation.name: Loop Area Calculation
area_calculation.correct: For circular loops, area is calculated using A = πr² where r is the radius.

A = πd².fix: A = πr². If given diameter, use r = d/2 first.
A = πd².action: Diameter = 2 × radius. Always convert to radius for area formula.

A = 2πr.action: Circumference is around the edge. Area is inside the circle.

A = πr.fix: A = πr². The radius must be squared.
A = πr.action: Units check: radius in m, area in m². Need r² to get m².

persistent.action: Memorise: Circumference = 2πr, Area = πr². Different purposes, different formulas.

unit_conversion_area.name: Area Unit Conversion
unit_conversion_area.correct: To convert cm² to m², divide by 10000 (or multiply by 10⁻⁴).

divide by 100.error: That converts cm to m, not cm² to m².
divide by 100.fix: Area conversion squares the linear conversion: (100)² = 10000.
divide by 100.action: 1 m = 100 cm, so 1 m² = 100² cm² = 10000 cm².

multiply by 100.fix: cm² to m² makes the number smaller. Divide by 10000.
multiply by 100.action: 1 cm² is much smaller than 1 m². The number must decrease.

divide by 10.error: Factor is way off for area conversion.
divide by 10.fix: For area, square the length conversion factor: 100² = 10000.
divide by 10.action: Think: 1 m² = 10000 cm². Reverse: 1 cm² = 0.0001 m².

persistent.gap: You don't understand how unit conversions scale for area.
persistent.action: Remember: length factor of 100 becomes area factor of 10000. Square the conversion.

flux_concept.title: Understanding Magnetic Flux
flux_concept.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of what magnetic flux is.

sentences.text: Magnetic flux is a measure of the total {{d1}} passing through a given area. It can be thought of as counting the number of {{d2}} that penetrate a surface.

d1.tooltip: What type of field does flux measure?

d2.tooltip: We visualise magnetic fields using what?

sentences.text: The SI unit of magnetic flux is the {{d3}}, which has the symbol {{d4}}. This unit is equivalent to one tesla multiplied by one square metre.

d3.tooltip: The unit of flux, not field strength.

sentences.text: Magnetic flux depends on both the {{d5}} of the magnetic field and the {{d6}} through which the field passes.

d5.tooltip: A stronger field gives more flux.

d6.tooltip: A larger loop catches more field.

flux_formula.title: The Magnetic Flux Formula
flux_formula.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show you understand how to calculate magnetic flux.

sentences.text: The formula for magnetic flux is Φ_B = {{d1}}, where B is the magnetic field strength measured in {{d2}} and A is the area measured in square metres.

d1.tooltip: Flux involves multiplying B and A.

d2.tooltip: The unit of magnetic field strength.

sentences.text: In the formula Φ_B = B⊥A, the subscript ⊥ indicates that only the {{d3}} component of the magnetic field contributes to the flux. This means the field must be at {{d4}} to the loop surface for maximum flux.

d3.tooltip: What direction relative to the area?

sentences.text: Magnetic flux is {{d5}} proportional to field strength, meaning doubling B will {{d6}} the flux.

d5.tooltip: Look at where B appears in the formula.

d6.tooltip: Direct proportion means same factor change.

angle_effects.title: How Angle Affects Magnetic Flux
angle_effects.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand how the orientation of a loop affects the magnetic flux through it.

sentences.text: When a loop is oriented with its plane perpendicular to the magnetic field, the flux through the loop is at its {{d1}} value, and the formula Φ = BA can be used directly.

d1.tooltip: Perpendicular orientation gives the most flux.

sentences.text: When a loop is oriented with its plane parallel to the magnetic field direction, the magnetic flux through it is {{d2}} because no field lines pass {{d3}} the loop surface.

d2.tooltip: No field penetrates a parallel loop.

d3.tooltip: Flux counts lines that penetrate the area.

sentences.text: As a loop rotates from perpendicular to parallel orientation in a magnetic field, the flux through it {{d4}} from maximum to zero. At intermediate angles, the flux has an {{d5}} value.

d4.tooltip: Moving away from perpendicular reduces flux.

flux_changes.title: Changing Magnetic Flux
flux_changes.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand how magnetic flux can be changed.

sentences.text: There are four main ways to change the magnetic flux through a loop: changing the {{d1}}, changing the {{d2}}, rotating the loop, or moving the loop in or out of the field region.

d1.tooltip: One of the two variables in Φ = BA.

d2.tooltip: The other variable in Φ = BA.

sentences.text: When calculating the area of a circular loop, the formula A = {{d3}} is used, where r is the {{d4}} of the circle.

d3.tooltip: The formula for circle area uses r squared.

d4.tooltip: The distance from centre to edge.

sentences.text: When converting area from cm² to m², you must divide by {{d5}} because area is a {{d6}}-dimensional quantity.

d6.tooltip: Area has units of length squared.

flux_concept.title: Applying Magnetic Flux Concepts
flux_concept.instructions: Apply your understanding of magnetic flux to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A coil of wire placed in a uniform magnetic field experiences magnetic flux, which can be visualised as the count of {{d1}} penetrating the {{d2}} enclosed by the coil.

d1.tooltip: How we represent magnetic fields visually.

d2.tooltip: Flux passes through the enclosed surface.

sentences.text: If a region has a high magnetic field strength, the field lines are drawn {{d3}} together. A loop in this region would have {{d4}} flux than the same loop in a weaker field.

d3.tooltip: Dense field lines indicate strong field.

d4.tooltip: Stronger field means more flux through same area.

sentences.text: The units of magnetic flux can be derived from the formula: if B is in tesla (T) and A is in m², then flux is in {{d5}}, which equals {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Units multiply just like the quantities.

flux_formula.title: Using the Flux Formula
flux_formula.instructions: Apply the magnetic flux formula to practical situations.

sentences.text: A rectangular loop with sides 20 cm and 30 cm has an area of {{d1}} m². To find the flux, this area is {{d2}} by the perpendicular magnetic field strength.

d1.tooltip: Convert cm² to m²: 600 cm² = 0.06 m².

sentences.text: If the magnetic field strength through a loop is tripled while the area remains constant, the magnetic flux will be {{d3}} because flux is {{d4}} proportional to field strength.

d4.tooltip: B appears in the numerator of Φ = BA.

sentences.text: For a circular coil with radius 10 cm in a 0.5 T field, the maximum flux is calculated using A = {{d5}} and then Φ = {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Convert 10 cm to 0.1 m, then use πr².

d6.tooltip: Φ = BA with B = 0.5 T and A = π × (0.1)² m².

angle_effects.title: Angle Effects in Practice
angle_effects.instructions: Apply your understanding of how angle affects magnetic flux.

sentences.text: A generator coil rotates in a magnetic field. When the coil face is directly facing the field (perpendicular), the flux is {{d1}}. When the coil has rotated 90° so its edge faces the field, the flux is {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Face-on to the field catches maximum flux.

d2.tooltip: Edge-on means no field passes through.

sentences.text: When the loop plane makes an angle with the field that is neither 0° nor 90°, the flux has a value {{d3}} maximum and zero. In VCE Physics, we only calculate flux when the field is {{d4}} to the area.

d4.tooltip: The ⊥ symbol in B⊥A means perpendicular.

sentences.text: The qualitative effect of increasing the angle between the loop normal and the field direction is that flux {{d5}}. At 90° between normal and field, the loop plane is {{d6}} to the field and flux is zero.

d5.tooltip: Tilting away from perpendicular reduces flux.

d6.tooltip: Normal perpendicular to field means plane parallel to field.

flux_changes.title: Practical Methods to Change Flux
flux_changes.instructions: Apply your understanding of how flux can be changed in real situations.

sentences.text: In an electromagnet, the magnetic field strength can be changed by varying the {{d1}}. This changes the flux through any nearby loop without moving the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What controls the field strength of an electromagnet?

d2.tooltip: The loop stays stationary; field changes.

sentences.text: A loop moving into a magnetic field region experiences {{d3}} flux. A loop moving out of the field region experiences {{d4}} flux.

d3.tooltip: Entering the field means more field through the loop.

d4.tooltip: Leaving the field means less field through the loop.

sentences.text: In a generator, the flux changes because the coil {{d5}} in the magnetic field. This is different from moving a loop in and out, where the flux changes because the loop {{d6}} the field region.

d5.tooltip: Rotation changes the angle between loop and field.

d6.tooltip: Moving in and out changes how much loop is in the field.

flux_concept.title: Mastering Magnetic Flux Concepts
flux_concept.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of magnetic flux concepts.

sentences.text: Students sometimes confuse magnetic flux (Φ) with magnetic field strength (B). The key difference is that flux depends on {{d1}}, while field strength is a property of {{d2}} in space.

d1.tooltip: What makes flux different from field strength?

d2.tooltip: B exists at every point; Φ is a total through an area.

sentences.text: The relationship between B and Φ can be understood by considering B as the flux {{d3}}, meaning B represents how much flux passes through each {{d4}} of area.

d3.tooltip: B = Φ/A, so B is flux per unit area.

d4.tooltip: B is in T = Wb/m², flux per area.

sentences.text: Two loops in the same uniform magnetic field will have different flux values if they have different {{d5}}. The loop with larger area has {{d6}} flux, assuming both loops are oriented {{d7}} to the field.

d6.tooltip: Larger area catches more field lines.

d7.tooltip: What orientation allows Φ = BA to apply?

flux_formula.title: Complete Flux Formula Understanding
flux_formula.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of the magnetic flux formula and its applications.

sentences.text: A common error is using Φ = BA without checking that the field is {{d1}} to the area. If the field is at an angle, the formula gives the {{d2}} possible flux for that field and area.

d2.tooltip: Φ = BA gives maximum; tilting reduces it.

sentences.text: When a circular loop of diameter 40 cm is placed perpendicular to a uniform field of 2.0 T, the radius is {{d3}} m and the flux is {{d4}} Wb.

d3.tooltip: Radius = diameter/2, then convert to metres.

sentences.text: If both the field strength and the loop area are doubled simultaneously, the flux becomes {{d5}} the original value because flux is {{d6}} proportional to both B and A.

angle_effects.title: Complete Understanding of Angle Effects
angle_effects.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of how orientation affects magnetic flux.

sentences.text: The distinction between 'loop perpendicular to field' and 'loop parallel to field' confuses many students. Perpendicular means the {{d1}} of the loop faces the field directly, giving {{d2}} flux.

d1.tooltip: Perpendicular orientation: face-on to the field.

d2.tooltip: Face-on catches the most field lines.

sentences.text: Parallel orientation means the {{d3}} of the loop faces the field, so field lines pass {{d4}} the loop without penetrating it.

d4.tooltip: Lines miss the loop interior entirely.

sentences.text: In a rotating generator, as the coil turns through one complete rotation, the flux varies from {{d5}} to zero to maximum (opposite direction) to zero and back to maximum. This cycle repeats {{d6}} for each rotation.

d5.tooltip: Starting position is typically maximum flux.

d6.tooltip: One complete rotation = one complete flux cycle.

flux_changes.title: Comprehensive Understanding of Flux Changes
flux_changes.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of how flux can be changed.

sentences.text: Electromagnetic induction requires a {{d1}} magnetic flux. A steady flux, no matter how large, produces {{d2}} induced EMF.

d2.tooltip: No change in flux means no induced EMF.

sentences.text: A loop entirely within a uniform magnetic field experiences {{d3}} change in flux when moved sideways, because the flux entering equals the flux leaving. Flux only changes when the loop {{d4}} the field boundary.

d3.tooltip: Uniform field, same area in field = constant flux.

d4.tooltip: Flux changes when entering or leaving the field.

sentences.text: For a loop being squeezed smaller while in a magnetic field, the flux {{d5}} because the {{d6}} decreases even though the field stays constant.

d6.tooltip: The area is what's changing in this scenario.
